text: The libretto, by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman, is largely a satire on the petty court surrounding an ageing poet, whose deeply egocentric character leads him to sacrifice everything to his need of inspiration. Henze obtains his musical characterisation by means of individual instrumental timbres and personal intervals, and the result is often less delineation of character than caricature. This is also the chief, or at least the most successfully executed trait of the libretto, which contains an odd blend of highly poetic phraseology and schoolboy humour.
